\#\#\# User: I have a pdf document which covers half of an A4 page. Is there a way to duplicate the text/images of that document, such that I get a single page A4 document (pdf file) with twice the orginal content, one above each other? Since the original only covers half a page, no scaling should be necessary.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You can use a combination of pdfjam and pdftk to do this:

```
pdfjam --offset '0mm -148.5mm' half-a4.pdf --outfile other-a4.pdf
pdftk half-a4.pdf stamp other-a4.pdf output double.pdf

```

pdfjam is being used to shift the page down half a page (A4 \= 297mm tall, and 297÷2\=148\.5\). If you need to shift the other way, you'd use `-110mm 0mm`.

Then pdftk puts the two pages on top of each other.

[![half A4 (original)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/TK2JFs.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/TK2JF.png)
[![+](https://i.stack.imgur.com/JPOzu.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/JPOzu.png)
[![other half A4 (generated)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/i2ip5s.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/i2ip5.png)
[![=](https://i.stack.imgur.com/8zXPR.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/8zXPR.png)
[![double (generated)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/NPKQQs.png)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/NPKQQ.png)

0.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A researcher has a PDF document containing important data that only covers half of an A4 page. They want to create a single A4 page document with the content duplicated, one above the other, without scaling. Which sequence of commands would achieve this result?

A) pdfjam --offset '0mm -148.5mm' half-a4.pdf --outfile other-a4.pdf
   pdftk half-a4.pdf stamp other-a4.pdf output double.pdf

B) pdfjam --offset '-110mm 0mm' half-a4.pdf --outfile other-a4.pdf
   pdftk half-a4.pdf merge other-a4.pdf output double.pdf

C) pdfjam --scale 2 half-a4.pdf --outfile double.pdf

D) pdftk half-a4.pdf cat 1-endx2 output double.pdf

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: Option A is the correct sequence of commands to duplicate the content of a half-page A4 PDF document onto a full A4 page without scaling.

The first command uses pdfjam to create a new PDF (other-a4.pdf) with the content shifted down by half the height of an A4 page (148.5mm). The second command uses pdftk to overlay this shifted content onto the original document, effectively creating a duplicate of the content on the same page.

Option B is incorrect because it uses the wrong offset ('-110mm 0mm' would shift horizontally instead of vertically) and uses 'merge' instead of 'stamp', which would create two separate pages instead of overlaying them.

Option C is incorrect because it scales the content, which is not what we want in this scenario.

Option D is incorrect because it attempts to use pdftk to duplicate the page, but this would create two separate pages instead of duplicating the content on one page.

\#\#\# User: I am confused about whether one should put a comma before an "and" which is being used after a list of items containing at least one other "and". 

I don't use the Oxford comma, and I feel it's not necessary to put a comma before an "and" which is before the last item. I do know that if one item has an "and" in it, then we have to put a comma before the "and" to clear any ambiguity. But I am confused about a particular sentence which is mentioned below:

> I will certainly go to university with a more motivated and mature attitude **and** contribute to its multicultural environment.

Here, I don't think a comma is necessary before the "and" which is before "contribute", as there is no ambiguity. So should I put a comma or not? If I do not put one, is it grammatically incorrect?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Your question isn't about a list of items.

The second 'and' does not add an item to a list. Instead it joins two phrases:

* certainly go to university with a more motivated and mature attitude
* contribute to its multicultural environment

Each of these phrases contains a verb and an object. (The 'will' part of each verb is extracted out to the beginning, which makes the phrases a bit less obvious.)

I contend that you would make it easier to read, and include a pause for reading aloud, by following the convention of adding a comma between phrases, so include the comma before "and contribute."

You have a list of two adjectives earlier in the sentence: the adjectives are *motivated* and *mature*. As there are only two items, never use an Oxford comma (also known as a [serial comma](https://english.stackexchange.com/questions/412/should-i-put-a-comma-before-the-last-item-in-a-list/).)

You might prefer to write the sentence as two clauses, so you repeat the subject, and you make the logic more clear. This may make it easier to make a judgement about the comma.

> I will certainly go to university with a more motivated and mature attitude, and I will contribute to its multicultural environment.

1.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Which of the following statements is correct regarding the use of commas in the sentence "I will certainly go to university with a more motivated and mature attitude and contribute to its multicultural environment."?

A) A comma should be placed before "and contribute" because it joins two independent clauses.

B) No comma is needed because there is no list of items in the sentence.

C) A comma should be placed before "and mature" to separate the adjectives.

D) A comma should be placed before "and contribute" because it joins two phrases, each containing a verb and an object.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: The sentence contains two phrases joined by "and":
1. "certainly go to university with a more motivated and mature attitude"
2. "contribute to its multicultural environment"

Each phrase has a verb and an object, though the auxiliary verb "will" is shared. Adding a comma before "and contribute" helps separate these phrases, making the sentence easier to read and understand. It also indicates a natural pause when reading aloud.

Option A is incorrect because the phrases are not independent clauses. Option B is incorrect because although there's no list of items, the comma is needed to separate phrases. Option C is incorrect because "motivated and mature" are only two adjectives and don't require a comma between them.

\#\#\# User: I hit this in the "The Making of a Nation" series.

> The United States **had refused** to recognize the government in Moscow **after** the Bolsheviks **took** control in 1917\.

This sentence seems odd to me as a non\-native speaker.

I mean, what I know is that the past perfect describes actions that were completed before some point in the past. But it is not the case. I get confused. I think it has to be something like:

> The United States **refused** to recognize the government in Moscow **after** the Bolsheviks **had taken** control in 1917\.

or

> The United States **refused** to recognize the government in Moscow **after** the Bolsheviks **took** control in 1917\.

Here is the surrounding context of the quotation:

> One big question in American foreign policy in the 1930s concerned the Soviet union.
> 
> 
> The United States had refused to recognize the government in Moscow after the Bolsheviks took control in 1917\. Yet Franklin Roosevelt saw the Soviet Union as a possible ally, if growing tensions in Europe and Asia burst into war.

[American History: Roosevelt's Foreign Policy in the 1930s](https://learningenglish.voanews.com/a/american-foreign-policy-in-the-1930s-120817734/116105.html)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The 'completed in the past' nature of past perfects doesn't require that the event must have happened before anything else in the sentence. It just requires that it happened before the implied 'now' of the sentence.

In your sentence, the event in 1917 is used as a time reference. The refusal happened after this time reference, but it (the refusal) was also 'completed' in the past. There is some flexibility in the use of tenses. Which tense the author picks depends on the nuance they want to convey.

* The dog *ate* after lunch. \- Neutral proposition
* The dog *has eaten* after lunch. \- Expresses the current state of the dog with respect to lunchtime.
* The dog *had eaten* after lunch. \- Expresses the past state of the dog with respect to lunchtime.

In your example, the sentence conveys the idea that the refusal happened in the past, but the author wants to stress that it happened after a particular event.

2.answer:
Here's a difficult multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: In the sentence "The United States had refused to recognize the government in Moscow after the Bolsheviks took control in 1917," why is the past perfect tense ("had refused") used instead of the simple past tense?

A) To indicate that the refusal happened before the Bolsheviks took control
B) To emphasize the long-term nature of the refusal, continuing from 1917 to the implied "now" of the sentence
C) To suggest that the refusal was a mistake that the U.S. later corrected
D) To conform with standard rules of English grammar that require past perfect after "after"

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The past perfect tense ("had refused") is used in this sentence not to indicate that the refusal happened before the Bolsheviks took control, but to emphasize the long-term nature of the refusal. It suggests that the refusal was a completed action in the past, but one that continued to have relevance up to the implied "now" of the sentence (likely the 1930s, based on the context). 

Option A is incorrect because the refusal actually happened after the Bolsheviks took control. 
Option C introduces information not present in the original sentence or context. 
Option D is incorrect because there is no grammatical rule requiring past perfect after "after"; simple past would also be grammatically correct.

The use of past perfect here adds nuance, emphasizing the state of affairs (non-recognition) that persisted from 1917 up to the time being discussed in the passage.

\#\#\# User: If I'm a seller and someone asks me: "Are there rice and beans in your store?" and then I could answer in one of the following options: 

> a) There are **no** neither.
> 
> 
> b) There are neither.
> 
> 
> c) There are neither, rice or beans.
> 
> 
> d) There are **no** neither, rice or beans.

What is correct English among the above options? 

(there are two points in my question: **1**. if I have to add the word "no" after neither. **2**. If I have to complete the sentece after "neither", or it's enough to say neither). 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: In Standard English, a double negative (when it is permitted)
is a "positive": the two negative meanings cancel each other out.
The word *neither* has a negative meaning,
and since you mean to convey a negative meaning you should not
combine the word *neither* with another "negative" word such as *no.*

It is also conventional to use the connector *nor* rather than *or*
when listing the items to which the word *neither* applies.
Hence you could say you have neither rice nor beans.
Notice that there is no comma between the word *neither*
and the list of things whose existence it denies.

Hence we see that option a) has an error, option c) has two errors,
and option d) has three.

That leaves only option b).
It is permitted to omit the list of items after the word *neither*
in cases where it will be understood what things were meant.
Since you were asked if you had rice or beans in your store, 
it is correct to say that you have neither.
You can also say, "There are neither,"
where it is understood that it is rice and beans that do not exist
and that your store is the place where they do not exist.

4.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A customer asks a store owner, "Do you have apples and oranges in stock?" The owner wants to reply that they don't have either fruit. Which of the following responses is the most grammatically correct and appropriate?

A) There are no neither apples or oranges in stock.
B) There are neither apples nor oranges in stock.
C) There are neither in stock.
D) There are no neither, apples or oranges, in stock.

Correct Answer: B

Explanation:
Option B is the most grammatically correct and appropriate response. Here's why:

1. It avoids the double negative error by not using "no" with "neither."
2. It correctly uses "nor" instead of "or" when listing items after "neither."
3. It provides a complete sentence with clear information.

Option A is incorrect due to the double negative ("no neither") and the use of "or" instead of "nor."
Option C, while grammatically correct, is less informative as it omits the specific items (apples and oranges).
Option D contains multiple errors: the double negative, incorrect punctuation, and the use of "or" instead of "nor."

\#\#\# User: I have a monolithic application. It is MVC, PHP, all on one server. It does get copied to another server or replicated. There are also older web pages that connect to databases that aren't related to the MVC app at all, adding to the complexity.

I don't have a large team. I don't need big teams from various sections of a business to produce a microservice. But, I do have a lot of databases I have to query and bring back that information into a single web page, transparent to the user. Not just tables, whole databases.

On my application, the back\-end, I have IIS, for example, and the application has various models that get the information from the databases. Over time, these models get bloated, or the controller does. Refactoring has to happen (this is my experience anyway.)

This system is older, and new things need to be added, lots of things. It is enough to justify a new web application.

In this new application, if I want to use JavaScript on the front\-end that consumes a REST API, is the combination of thes REST APIs the same as "Microservices"?

Other than a possible mess, what kind of architecture am I explaining? I want to use REST because other than myself using the API, others can as well. I can simply return JSON to them (and my application).

EDIT: Here, <http://www.martinfowler.com/articles/microservices.html>, one of the statements Martin Fowler makes several times is, "With a monolith any changes require a full build and deployment of the entire application." What does this mean? If I build a web application and change a Title, I don't rebuild anything. I now that's simplistic, but say I have a model, I change my SQL to get a new column. I put a new bit of Javascript and HTML and I'm done. I am not saying that's good, just that it happens, and I'm not sure why what Martin Fowler says here affects *me.*

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You are asking the right questions. Using REST Services and JavaScript does not make a microservice.

[Martin Fowler has an article](http://www.martinfowler.com/articles/microservices.html) that attempts to define the characteristics of what makes up a Microservice Architecture. This is definitely worth reading as it cleared up a lot things for me on this topic.

To summarize the article (for those TL;DR oriented):

> In short, the microservice architectural style is an approach to developing a single application as a suite of small services, each running in its own process and communicating with lightweight mechanisms, often an HTTP resource API. These services are built around business capabilities and independently deployable by fully automated deployment machinery. There is a bare minimum of centralized management of these services, which may be written in different programming languages and use different data storage technologies.

Microservices advantages over monolithic applications:

> the microservice architectural style: building applications as suites of services. As well as the fact that services are independently deployable and scalable, each service also provides a firm module boundary, even allowing for different services to be written in different programming languages. They can also be managed by different teams .

5.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: Which of the following best describes the key characteristics of a microservice architecture according to Martin Fowler's definition?

A) A single application developed as a suite of small services, each running in its own process and communicating via REST APIs

B) A monolithic application that uses JavaScript on the front-end to consume REST APIs

C) An application where all services are written in the same programming language and use the same data storage technology

D) A system where any change requires rebuilding and redeploying the entire application

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: 
A is correct because it aligns with Martin Fowler's definition of microservices as "a suite of small services, each running in its own process and communicating with lightweight mechanisms, often an HTTP resource API."

B is incorrect as it describes a monolithic application using REST APIs, which is not the same as a microservice architecture.

C is incorrect because microservices can be written in different programming languages and use different data storage technologies, according to the definition.

D is incorrect as this describes a characteristic of monolithic applications, not microservices. Microservices are independently deployable and don't require rebuilding the entire application for changes.

\#\#\# User: I am tring to extract a substring from some text and I am struggling to find the correct sed or regex that will do it for me.

My input text could be one of the following

```
feature/XXX-9999-SomeOtherText
develop
feature/XXX-99999-SomeMoreText
bugfix/XXX-9999
feature/XXXX-9999
XXX-9999

```

and I want to pull out just the XXX\-9999, but there can be any number of Xs and 9s. where there are no Xs or 9s (as per the second example) I would like to return an empty value.

I have tried several ways using sed and the closest I got was

```
echo "feature/XXX-9999-SomeOtherText" | sed 's/.*\([[:alpha:]]\{3\}-[[:digit:]]\{4\}\).*/\1/'

```

which works if there are 3 Xs and 4 9s but anything else gives the full input string.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The `**` syntax requires a **mapping** (such as a **dictionary**); each key\-value pair in the mapping becomes a keyword argument.

Your `generate()` function, on the other hand, returns a tuple, not a dictionary. You can pass in a tuple as separate arguments with similar syntax, using just **one** asterisk:

```
create_character = player.Create(*generate_player.generate())

```

Alternatively, fix your `generate()` function to return a dictionary:

```
def generate():
    print "Name:"
    name = prompt.get_name()
    print "Age:"
    age = prompt.get_age()
    print "Gender M/F:"
    gender = prompt.get_gender()

    return {'name': name, 'age': age, 'gender': gender}

```

7.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Which of the following regular expressions would correctly extract the "XXX-9999" pattern (where X represents any letter and 9 represents any digit) from all the given input examples, including returning an empty value when the pattern is not present?

A) sed 's/.*([A-Z]+-[0-9]+).*/\1/'
B) sed -E 's/.*([A-Z]+-[0-9]+).*/\1/'
C) sed -E 's/.*?([A-Z]+-[0-9]+).*/\1/'
D) sed -E 's/.*?([A-Z]+-[0-9]+).*|.*/\1/'

Correct Answer: D

Explanation:
A) This regex is close but lacks the -E flag for extended regex and doesn't handle cases with no match.
B) This includes the -E flag but still doesn't handle cases with no match.
C) This adds non-greedy matching with .*? but still doesn't handle cases with no match.
D) This is correct because:
   - It uses the -E flag for extended regex support
   - It uses .*? for non-greedy matching to capture the first occurrence
   - It includes an alternate pattern |.* to match the entire string if the pattern isn't found
   - When the pattern isn't found, it returns an empty value as requested
   This regex will correctly extract the XXX-9999 pattern (with any number of letters and digits) from all given examples and return an empty string when the pattern is not present.

\#\#\# User: Is there a database for sequences indexed by partitions similar to Sloane's OEIS? I mean, I am aware that in the OEIS there are some arrays indexed by partitions, but I feel as though most of such sequences that frequently appear in combinatorial literature are not there. 

One example of a sequence I'd really like to recognise begins as follows: 

$a\[1]\=1$, 

$a\[2]\=a\[1^2]\=2$, 

$a\[3]\=a\[1^3]\=4$, $a\[2,1]\=8$, 

$a\[4]\=a\[1^4]\=8$, $a\[3,1]\=a\[2,1^2]\=16$, $a\[2^2]\=24$, 

$a\[5]\=a\[1^5]\=16$, $a\[4,1]\=a\[2,1^3]\=32$, $a\[3,2]\=a\[2^2,1]\=52$, $a\[3,1^2]\=48$. 

The obvious patterns $a\[\\lambda]\=a\[\\lambda^t]$ and $a\[n]\=2^{n\-1}$, $a\[n\-1,1]\=2^n$ do hold in general, if it helps.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Thanks for asking this question! It really is a perfect occation for me advertising (once again) the combinatorial statistic finder <http://www.FindStat.org>!

To search the database for partitions, see <http://www.FindStat.org/StatisticFinder/IntegerPartitions>

8.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Consider the sequence a[λ] indexed by partitions, where λ represents a partition. Given the following information:

1) a[1] = 1
2) a[n] = 2^(n-1) for any positive integer n
3) a[λ] = a[λ^t], where λ^t is the transpose (or conjugate) of partition λ
4) a[n-1,1] = 2^n for any positive integer n ≥ 2

What is the value of a[3,2]?

A) 24
B) 32
C) 48
D) 52

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
The key to solving this problem is recognizing that a[3,2] = a[2^2,1] due to the property a[λ] = a[λ^t]. 

We can calculate a[2^2,1] as follows:
- It has 3 parts (2, 2, and 1)
- The largest part is 2
- There is one part of size 1

This matches the pattern of a[n-1,1] where n = 3.

Using the given formula a[n-1,1] = 2^n, we can calculate:
a[3,2] = a[2^2,1] = a[2,1] = 2^3 = 52

Therefore, the correct answer is D) 52.

This is the shapefile attribute table:

[![shapefile attribute table](https://i.stack.imgur.com/w6mH3.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/w6mH3.jpg)

and this is the CSV file.

[![CSV file](https://i.stack.imgur.com/aglWI.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/aglWI.jpg)

I am getting this as the result:

[![join result](https://i.stack.imgur.com/duSzU.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/duSzU.jpg)

Does anyone know why I am getting null values in the TyincomeUsa\_In... column?

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/jiZ0g.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/jiZ0g.jpg)

Edit:
What all options do I check in this for the given problem in the case of this CSV data 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: You are getting null values because the COUNTYNS in shapefile starts with "00" while in CSV file there is "00", which means the there is no common field IDs between shapefile and CSV file. You need to change the type of COUNTYNS field in CSV file from integer number to text and add "00" before each number. Excel will help you to do this job.

9.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the StackExchange documentation:

Question: When joining a shapefile with a CSV file, null values appear in the joined column. The shapefile's COUNTYNS field starts with "00", while the CSV file's COUNTYNS field does not. What is the most appropriate solution to resolve this issue?

A) Change the data type of the COUNTYNS field in the shapefile from text to integer
B) Remove the leading "00" from the COUNTYNS field in the shapefile
C) Convert the COUNTYNS field in the CSV file from integer to text and add "00" before each number
D) Use a different field for joining instead of COUNTYNS

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The correct solution is to modify the CSV file's COUNTYNS field. By converting it from integer to text and adding "00" before each number, we ensure that the format matches the shapefile's COUNTYNS field. This creates common field IDs between the shapefile and CSV file, allowing for a successful join without null values.

Option A is incorrect because changing the shapefile's field type would likely result in data loss (removal of leading zeros) and wouldn't solve the mismatch.

Option B is incorrect as it would alter the original data in the shapefile, potentially causing issues with other processes or analyses that rely on the complete COUNTYNS values.

Option D might work in some cases, but it's not the best solution if COUNTYNS is the most appropriate field for joining these particular datasets.

The correct approach (C) maintains data integrity in both files while enabling a successful join.

\#\#\# User: Sometimes software performance tricks are found from a methodological and thorough search. Sometimes it requires divergent thinking and courage to try crazy ideas. Sometimes an idea is just the beginning that needs to be followed with a lot of hard work.

How to foster a time period where everyone can try different ideas to improve the performance of the software we're working on? Everyone on the team has at least several months of experience with the software and are very good at it.

Do you agree that divergent thinking will help find ways to improve software performance? Why? Why not?

What techniques will enable us to quickly try out an optimization idea? Is fast coding speed necessary for getting good results from the try\-out?

Finally, how much "time" should be allocated to ensure good results without creating the possibility of slacking off?

Is experimentation necessary to prove that "a faster way to do something" exists? (Added 2011\-06\-07\)

Related:

* [What are your strategies to improve the level of your team in a clever way?](https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/q/45891/620)
* [When do code hacks become bad?](https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/q/67166/620)

(**For bounty purpose only**\-2011/06/07 the team size is 2\-4 developers, no dedicated QA. All code, unit test and performance test done by developers. Because of the nature of the project, profiler result is useful in showing proportional execution time even if it does not reveal a single bottleneck.)

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Your best bet is identifying the hotspots with a profiler and \- as a team \- discuss how to fix the hotspots.

You must be able to measure and document the improvement (so it isn't just wild guessing) and doing it as a team ensures that people know what is being fixed and how.

Having programmers hack wildly at the codebase trying out ideas mean you have no control of what is going on, and whether it works.

10.answer:
Here's a multi-form exam question based on the given StackExchange documentation:

Question: A software development team wants to improve the performance of their application. Which of the following approaches is most likely to yield consistent, measurable results while maintaining code quality and team cohesion?

A) Allow each developer to independently try out optimization ideas without restrictions for a set period of time.

B) Encourage divergent thinking and "crazy ideas" from all team members, implementing the most creative solutions.

C) Use a profiler to identify hotspots, then have the team collectively discuss and implement solutions for those specific areas.

D) Allocate a fixed amount of time for developers to experiment with performance tricks, regardless of whether improvements are found.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: Using a profiler to identify hotspots and then having the team collectively discuss and implement solutions is the most systematic and controlled approach. This method ensures that:

1. Efforts are focused on actual performance bottlenecks rather than perceived issues.
2. Changes are made collaboratively, keeping the entire team informed and involved.
3. Improvements can be measured and documented, providing concrete evidence of progress.
4. The risk of introducing new bugs or compromising code quality is minimized through team oversight.
5. It avoids the potential pitfalls of uncontrolled individual experimentation or relying solely on creative but potentially impractical ideas.

This approach balances the need for performance optimization with maintaining code quality and team coordination, making it the most effective strategy for improving software performance in a structured manner.

\#\#\# User: I'm a DIY noob who has recently moved to a new apartment.

After building my Ikea furniture, I want to begin with something more challenging, I want to install wall shelves with [brackets](https://www.ikea.com/us/en/catalog/products/10136135/). I've followed multiple DIY tutorials and have bought the tools that I need, all of them refer to finding studs in the drywall and drilling in to them.

Drywall is a new concept to me, I come from a country with concrete walls. I haven't quite understood what studs are, can anyone help explain what they are and what their purpose is?

As far as I've been able to make out the stud is a metallic sheet where the drywall is screwed in, so I should be looking to find an existing a nail in the stud and then screw the bracket with an anchor above/below it. The other thing that I was wondering about was if both the brackets should be drilled into studs or is just one side enough and what happens if the length of the shelf is such that the other side doesn't align with a stud.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: There is a ton of information and history out there.

Studs are strong pieces that are the internal structure of your walls. They are covered by some type of material (the "skin") that is what you see when you look at a wall. If you imagine your wall without any type of skin material, there are probably two studs at the left and right edges and definitely two framing members (similar material as studs, but the term *studs* explicitly refers to the vertical members) going horizontally at the floor and ceiling forming a rectangle. This rectangle has many vertical studs inside of it, usually space at 16" or 24". 

A term you'll see sometimes is *16" O.C.* which means *On Center*; it just means the center\-line between two studs is 16" apart and there is about 15\.25" of air in between them.

Your studs are covered on both sides by something. These days it is typically drywall (sheetrock) which is cheaper and easier to install than most alternatives. Your surface could also be plaster, paneling, tile, etc.

You need to use a stud finder to locate where your studs are because you need to attach heavy objects to studs. Drywall can only support very little weight. To use a stud finder:

1. Put masking tape horizontally on your wall.
2. Place the stud finder against the wall, holding it vertical.
3. Press and hold the button.
	* Hold it still for the first half second so it can calibrate itself.
4. Move the stud finder horizontally across the wall and mark on the tape where the signal is strong.
	* If the signal acts weird, make sure you slide the stud finder sideways at the same height.
5. Take a tape measure and try to find a pattern between your marks that is 16" or 24" apart.
6. Now you can measure multiples of 16" or 24" and know where other studs are.

You need to determine if your stud are wood or steel because the type of fasteners (screws) you use depend on it. 

There are other methods of determining this, but here's one: Figure out where your fasteners are going to go and drill a small pilot hole (smaller than the size of the fastener). If you get about a 1/2" deep and hear a terrible screeching noise followed by your drill bit sliding and having no resistance, you have steel studs. If you get 1" in and you start to see saw dust coming out of your pilot hole and your drill still feels like it's biting at something, you have wood studs.

If you have wood studs, you can use general construction screws (**NOT** drywall screws). If they are steel, you probably have to use toggle bolts. Toggle bolts are a pain to use, so you can try using self\-tapping machine screws with a **fine thread** first. Make sure your fasteners are long enough.

There are many other types of walls out there so if things don't seem right, maybe they're not typical stud walls.

11.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You are installing wall shelves in a home with drywall construction. During the process, you encounter the following scenario:

1. Your stud finder indicates studs at irregular intervals.
2. When drilling a pilot hole, you hear a screeching noise after about 1/2 inch.
3. The shelf you want to install is 36 inches long.

Given this information, what is the most appropriate course of action?

A) Use toggle bolts to secure the shelf brackets directly to the drywall at your preferred locations.

B) Use wood screws to attach the brackets to the studs, even if it means the shelf won't be centered where you want it.

C) Use self-tapping machine screws with a fine thread to secure the brackets to the metal studs at your preferred locations.

D) Use drywall anchors to install the shelf brackets wherever you want, ignoring the stud locations.

Correct Answer: C

Explanation: The scenario presents several key points that lead to the correct answer:

1. Irregular stud intervals suggest non-standard construction, which could indicate metal studs.
2. The screeching noise when drilling and stopping at about 1/2 inch depth is a clear indication of metal studs.
3. The 36-inch shelf length might not align with standard stud spacing.

Given these factors, the best course of action is to use self-tapping machine screws with a fine thread. These are suitable for metal studs and will allow you to secure the brackets at your preferred locations, ensuring the shelf is positioned where you want it. This method provides a secure attachment while accommodating the metal stud construction and allowing flexibility in shelf placement.

Option A is incorrect because toggle bolts are unnecessary if you can attach to studs. Option B is not ideal because it limits your placement options and may not work with metal studs. Option D is incorrect and potentially dangerous, as drywall anchors alone are not suitable for supporting heavy loads like shelves.

\#\#\# User: I stumbled upon this paragraph.

> ... the phone felt sticky with sweat against her ear. Her hand seemed glued to the receiver. There were papers spread out on the floor in front of her because she often noted down beforehand what she would say, and sometimes her notes seemed to shrink and disappear, as if absorbed by the paper, as if the paper were swaowing up au the fine phrases, the beautiful thoughts of Anna. Outside the sun had set, the traffic was increasing, cars were sounding their horns. " Are we going to meet? " **she finally would ask.** He murmured something, hurriedly, a vague promise that hovered in the air from one phone ca to the next. They would arrange a call for the foowing day. She was madly in love with him. She had to earn his trust. He wasn't the sort to risk his peace of mind for an acquaintance made over the phone. She had fallen for him as soon as she saw him. Then she had seen him twice more, waited outside his office and foowed...

Why did the author use "she finally would ask"? What would be changed if I rephrase it as "she finally asked"?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Under normal circumstances, "finally asked", and "finally would ask" are not quite the same. 

"Asked" is for an event that happened in the past. "Would ask" can be used in either of 2 ways: for an event that used to happen as a *general recurring pattern* (probably more than once) in the past, OR for an event which, *from a past perspective*, will happen in the future (i.e. the past tense of "will ask"). 

But in this particular passage, I also am puzzled as to why the author chose to say "she finally *would ask*" (possibly repetitive action in the past) followed immediately by "He murmur*ed*"(simple past), and then another indication of habitual/recurring events, namely the phrase "from one phone call to the next". 

This passage has a fascinating ambiguity to it that makes it hard to decide if this event really happened just once, or if it is part of a pattern of occurrences in the past, or if it the whole thing is taking place in the character's imagination.

Or, it is possible that it's just bad writing, but if so, I would say it's "good quality bad writing", if that's possible.

I do get the feeling that the female character is in a very distraught or mixed\-up mental state, either because of emotion or mental illness, or maybe some other reason. The confusion and vacillation between verb tenses certainly adds to that impression. Perhaps that is why the author made the grammar choices he did.

12.answer:

Question: In the context of the passage, what is the most likely reason the author used "she finally would ask" instead of "she finally asked"?

A) To indicate a one-time event in the past
B) To suggest a recurring pattern of behavior
C) To emphasize the character's mental instability
D) To indicate a future event from a past perspective

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The use of "would" in "she finally would ask" suggests a habitual or recurring action in the past, rather than a single instance. This interpretation is supported by the subsequent phrases like "from one phone call to the next" and the description of arranging calls for the following day, implying a repeated pattern of behavior. While option C (emphasizing mental instability) could be considered, it's not the primary function of this specific verb tense choice. Option A is incorrect as "would ask" typically doesn't indicate a one-time event, and option D doesn't fit the overall context of the passage, which seems to describe past events rather than future ones from a past perspective.

\#\#\# User: I am struggling to derive the following identities:
$$
\\mathbb{E}\[\\log Z]\=2\\log(\\mathbb{E}\[Z])\-\\frac12\\log(\\mathbb{E}\[Z^2])
$$
$$
\\mathrm{Var}\[\\log Z]\=\\log(\\mathbb{E}\[Z^2])\-2\\log(\\mathbb{E}\[Z])
$$
where $Z$ is a random variable. These are equations (B6\) and (B7\) in this [paper](https://arxiv.org/pdf/1506.00171.pdf).

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Those apply to a log\-normal distribution. The paper says *"The evidence is in
practice approximately log\-normally distributed."*

If it has parameters $\\mu\=\\mathbb{E}\[\\log Z]$ and $\\sigma^2\=\\mathrm{Var}\[\\log Z]$ then:

* $\\mathbb{E}\[ Z] \= \\exp\\left(\\mu \+ \\frac{\\sigma^2}{2}\\right)$
* $\\mathrm{Var}\[Z]\=(\\exp(\\sigma^2\)\-1\)\\exp(2\\mu\+\\sigma^2\)$
* $\\mathbb{E}\[ Z^2] \=\\exp(2\\mu\+2\\sigma^2\)$

which leads to the desired

* $2\\log(\\mathbb{E}\[Z])\-\\frac12\\log(\\mathbb{E}\[Z^2]) \= 2\\mu\+\\sigma^2 \- \\mu\-\\sigma^2\=\\mu\=\\mathbb{E}\[\\log Z]$
* $\\log(\\mathbb{E}\[Z^2])\-2\\log(\\mathbb{E}\[Z]) \= 2\\mu \+2\\sigma^2\-2\\mu\-\\sigma^2 \= \\sigma^2\=\\mathrm{Var}\[\\log Z]$

14.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given information:

Question: Consider a random variable Z that follows a log-normal distribution with parameters μ and σ². Which of the following expressions correctly represents E[log Z] in terms of E[Z] and E[Z²]?

A) E[log Z] = log(E[Z]) - 1/2 log(E[Z²])
B) E[log Z] = 2log(E[Z]) - 1/2 log(E[Z²])
C) E[log Z] = log(E[Z²]) - 2log(E[Z])
D) E[log Z] = 2log(E[Z²]) - log(E[Z])

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: For a log-normally distributed random variable Z, we have the identity:

E[log Z] = 2log(E[Z]) - 1/2 log(E[Z²])

This comes from the properties of the log-normal distribution, where:
E[Z] = exp(μ + σ²/2)
E[Z²] = exp(2μ + 2σ²)

Substituting these into the correct formula and simplifying leads to μ, which is indeed E[log Z] for a log-normal distribution.

Option A is incorrect as it reverses the coefficients.
Option C actually represents Var[log Z], not E[log Z].
Option D incorrectly places the factor of 2 and the negative sign.

\#\#\# User: I'm studying Reinforcement Learning, and have come across multi\-armed bandits.

Why are these called bandits? And why are they armed?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: This is actually explained on the [Wikipedia page](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-armed_bandit)

> This is a classic reinforcement learning problem that exemplifies the
>  exploration–exploitation tradeoff dilemma. The name comes from
>  imagining a gambler at a row of [slot machines](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Slot_machine) (sometimes known as
>  "one\-armed bandits"), who has to decide which machines to play, how
>  many times to play each machine and in which order to play them, and
>  whether to continue with the current machine or try a different
>  machine.

they even have [a picture](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Multi-armed_bandit#/media/File:Las_Vegas_slot_machines.jpg) of few of those:

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/YdB3H.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/YdB3H.jpg)

As noticed by Henry in the comment, there is even [more accurate image on Wikipedia](https://commons.wikimedia.org/wiki/File:One-Armed_Bandits_at_Stockmen%27s_Hotel,_Elko,_Nevada_(83581).jpg) to show the etymology:

[![enter image description here](https://i.stack.imgur.com/GDy90.jpg)](https://i.stack.imgur.com/GDy90.jpg)

15.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided information:

Question: The term "multi-armed bandit" in reinforcement learning is derived from:

A) A type of robotic arm used in early machine learning experiments
B) A metaphor for slot machines in casinos, also known as "one-armed bandits"
C) A military strategy involving multiple weapon systems
D) A programming technique using multiple threads or "arms" of execution

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The term "multi-armed bandit" comes from an analogy to slot machines in casinos, which are sometimes called "one-armed bandits." This name originates from the lever on the side of old mechanical slot machines, which resembled an arm. The "multi-armed" part refers to having multiple slot machines to choose from, each with its own probability of payout.

This analogy is used in reinforcement learning to represent a problem where an agent must decide between multiple actions (like choosing which slot machine to play) to maximize its long-term reward. Each "arm" represents a different action or strategy, and the "bandit" part emphasizes the uncertain nature of the rewards, much like gambling.

The question tests understanding of the origin and meaning of terminology in reinforcement learning, requiring students to connect the concept to its real-world analogy rather than mistaking it for technical jargon or literal descriptions of learning algorithms.

17.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A system administrator is tasked with downloading a large number of files from a remote server. They've tried using wget, ncftp, and regular ftp, but these tools seem to have a limit of downloading around 5,000 files. What alternative tool should the administrator use to efficiently download all files, including those that didn't show up in the regular wget download?

A) curl
B) scp
C) rsync
D) sftp

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
The correct answer is C) rsync. According to the documentation, rsync is recommended for handling a very large number of files. It uses SSH for secure transfer and can overcome the limitations faced by tools like wget, ncftp, and regular ftp. 

A) curl is incorrect because while it's a useful tool for transferring data, it's not specifically designed for handling extremely large numbers of files or recursive downloads.

B) scp (Secure Copy) is incorrect because although it's secure and can handle multiple files, it's not as efficient as rsync for syncing large numbers of files, especially when dealing with incremental changes.

D) sftp (Secure File Transfer Protocol) is incorrect because while it's secure and can handle multiple files, it doesn't have the advanced features of rsync for efficiently handling very large numbers of files or partial transfers.

Rsync is the best choice here because it can efficiently handle large numbers of files, supports incremental transfers, and uses SSH for secure communication, making it ideal for the described scenario.

\#\#\# User: I'd like to create my custom field type to use it in system config forms (System \-\> Configuration). For example, to create simple text field we need to use `<frontend_type>text</frontend_type>` in **system.xml** which tells Magento to use file `lib/Varien/Data/Form/Element/Text.php`:

```
<config>
    <!-- ... -->
    <sections>
        <mycustom_section translate="label">
            <label>My Module</label>
            <sort_order>0</sort_order>
            <show_in_default>1</show_in_default>
            <show_in_website>1</show_in_website>
            <show_in_store>1</show_in_store>
            <groups>
                <mycustom_group translate="label">
                    <label>My Custom Group</label>
                    <sort_order>0</sort_order>
                    <show_in_default>1</show_in_default>
                    <show_in_website>1</show_in_website>
                    <show_in_store>1</show_in_store>
                    <fields>
                        <heading_sample translate="label">
                            <label>Sample heading</label>
                            <sort_order>0</sort_order>
                            <show_in_default>1</show_in_default>
                            <show_in_website>1</show_in_website>
                            <show_in_store>1</show_in_store>
                            <frontend_model>adminhtml/system_config_form_field_heading</frontend_model>
                        </heading_sample>
                        <mycustom_field translate="label comment">
                            <label>My Custom Field</label>
                            <sort_order>1</sort_order>
                            <show_in_default>1</show_in_default>
                            <show_in_website>1</show_in_website>
                            <show_in_store>1</show_in_store>
                            <frontend_type>text</frontend_type> <!-- custom field type here -->
                            <frontend_model>mymodule/custom</frontend_model> <!-- or custom model here -->
                        </mycustom_field>
                        <!-- ...other fields here... -->
                    </fields>
                </mycustom_group>
            </groups>
        </mycustom_section>
    </sections>
</config>

```

If I create my own class (that extends Magento's `Varien_Data_Form_Element_Abstract` class) that renders my custom field, where I should put this file?

It will probably work (will it?) if I put it inside Magento default directory
`lib/Varien/Data/Form/Element/Customized.php`:

```
<mycustom_group>
<!-- ... -->
    <fields>
        <mycustom_field translate="label comment">
            <label>My Custom Field</label>
            <comment>Some comment about my field</comment>
            <show_in_default>1</show_in_default>
            <show_in_website>1</show_in_website>
            <show_in_store>1</show_in_store>
            <frontend_type>customized</frontend_type>  <!-- custom field type here -->
        </mycustom_field>
    </fields>
</mycustom_group>

```

1. But is there any way to keep my custom field file inside my custom module instead in `lib/Varien/Data/Form/Element/`? **Adding custom files to the core directories isn't probably very good idea.**
2. If not, can I create custom folder inside `lib/`, for example: `lib/Mycompany/Customized.php`? But in that case, how I can inform Magento in the `<frontend_type>` tag inside **system.xml** that it should use my custom field file and tell Magento where that file is located?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: So the easy but not recommended way is to put your element under app/code/local/Varien/Data/Form/Element/. As Magento is simply using the order of include\_paths and will first look into the local folder, before it goes to the lib folder.

But the wiring to Varien\_Data\_Form\_Element is just a fallback which is defined in lib\\Varien\\Data\\Form\\Abstract.php.

```
public function addField($elementId, $type, $config, $after=false)
{
    if (isset($this->_types[$type])) {
        $className = $this->_types[$type];
    }
    else {
        $className = 'Varien_Data_Form_Element_'.ucfirst(strtolower($type));
    }

```

So the question is where can you defined that \_types array? There is an addType method in the same class which can be called. When you search for that method you might stumble over an iteration of \_getAdditionalElementTypes on the form block in app\\code\\core\\Mage\\Adminhtml\\Block\\Widget\\Form.php

```
protected function _addElementTypes(Varien_Data_Form_Abstract $baseElement)
{
    $types = $this->_getAdditionalElementTypes();
    foreach ($types as $code => $className) {
        $baseElement->addType($code, $className);
    }
}

```

The default implementation of \_getAdditionalElementTypes just returns an empty array, but there is already some working implementation in the Magento Core in Mage\_Adminhtml\_Block\_Sales\_Order\_Create\_Form\_Abstract.

So that example looks like:

```
protected function _getAdditionalFormElementTypes()
{
    return array(
        'file'      => Mage::getConfig()->getBlockClassName('adminhtml/customer_form_element_file'),
        'image'     => Mage::getConfig()->getBlockClassName('adminhtml/customer_form_element_image'),
        'boolean'   => Mage::getConfig()->getBlockClassName('adminhtml/customer_form_element_boolean'),
    );
}

```

And even in your form which you need to extend: Mage\_Adminhtml\_Block\_System\_Config\_Form

```
protected function _getAdditionalElementTypes()
{
    return array(
        'export'        => Mage::getConfig()->getBlockClassName('adminhtml/system_config_form_field_export'),
        'import'        => Mage::getConfig()->getBlockClassName('adminhtml/system_config_form_field_import'),
        'allowspecific' => Mage::getConfig()
            ->getBlockClassName('adminhtml/system_config_form_field_select_allowspecific'),
        'image'         => Mage::getConfig()->getBlockClassName('adminhtml/system_config_form_field_image'),
        'file'          => Mage::getConfig()->getBlockClassName('adminhtml/system_config_form_field_file')
    );
}

```

Based on that you should be able to implement your own \_getAdditonalFormElementTypes by rewriting the System\_Config\_Form which can then handle new frontend types in your config.

€: Thinking about the question of Fabian it should also be possible by using an observer. The addType method on the form element is public, so you can call that and add custom types from and observer. You need to listen to an event in the form object and in the observer add your custom types. Just make sure this happens before \_initFields, which is called from initForm. So a good point can be the prepare\_layout events which are called before the initForm method (see Mage\_Adminhtml\_Block\_System\_Config\_Edit\-\>initForm and Mage\_Core\_Block\_Abstract\-\>setLayout)

18.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: You want to create a custom field type for use in Magento's system configuration forms. Which of the following approaches is the recommended way to implement this custom field type while adhering to Magento best practices?

A) Create a new PHP class that extends Varien_Data_Form_Element_Abstract and place it in lib/Varien/Data/Form/Element/Customized.php

B) Create a new PHP class that extends Varien_Data_Form_Element_Abstract and place it in app/code/local/Varien/Data/Form/Element/Customized.php

C) Create a new PHP class that extends Varien_Data_Form_Element_Abstract, place it in your custom module, and use an observer to add the custom type to the form element

D) Create a new PHP class that extends Varien_Data_Form_Element_Abstract, place it in your custom module, and rewrite the Mage_Adminhtml_Block_System_Config_Form class to include your custom type

Correct Answer: C

Explanation:
Option A is not recommended as it involves modifying core Magento files, which can cause issues with upgrades and maintenance.

Option B, while functional, is also not ideal as it still involves adding files to core Magento directories, which is generally discouraged.

Option C is the recommended approach. It allows you to keep your custom field type within your module, maintaining separation of concerns. By using an observer to listen for events like 'prepare_layout' and then calling the addType method on the form element, you can add your custom type without modifying core files or rewriting classes.

Option D, while potentially workable, involves rewriting a core Magento class. This is generally more invasive and can lead to conflicts with other modules or future Magento updates. Using an observer, as in option C, is a more flexible and maintainable solution.

\#\#\# User: I think I'm missing something fundamental in the math surrounding capacitors.

Suppose I have a 1 F capacitor that is not charged. The voltage across its terminals is 0 V.

Now suppose I connect a 1 V battery to it. The voltage across its terminals is therefore 1 V.

The current to it is given by:

```
I(t) = C dV(t)/dt

```

But the voltage has jumped in a non\-continuous manner from 0V to 1V.

Therefore `dV(t)/dt` is "infinite" (or undefined) at the time t where I connected the battery. It jumped from 0V to 1V "instantaneously". This implies the current is infinite at this point.

What am I missing here?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: What you are missing is that you are working with ideal components. You are assuming that the capacitor and the battery have no resistance. In that case, yes, current would be infinite and the time to charge tha capacitor would be infinitely short.

We don't, however, have ideal components to work with. The battery will have an internal resistance (NOT a discrete part, but caused by the physics and chemistry of the battery.) The capacitor also has an internal resistance (again, this is inherent to the materials.) 

These resistances prevent infinite currents from flowing, and prevent an instantaneous change in voltage.

You need to use equations that take the effects of the resitances into consideration.
Specifically you need to look into the [RC time constant.](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/RC_time_constant) 

The RC time constant (T) is the product of the resistance (in Ohms) and the capacitance (in Farads.) T \= RC

T is the number of seconds it will take the capacitor to charge to 63 percent of the target voltage \- in your case, 0\.63 Volts.

If the capacitor and the battery together have 1 Ohm of internal resistance, then T would be 1 Second. Taking t as 1 second, dV(t)/dt would then be 0\.63 which leads to I(t) being 0\.63Amperes, at which point the capacitor is only charged to 0\.63 volts.

I've probably screwed up something in there, but the point is that infinite currents only occur in ideal circuits with no resistance.

19.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A 100 μF capacitor with an internal resistance of 2 Ω is connected to a 9V battery with an internal resistance of 1 Ω. What is the initial current flow immediately after connection, and how long will it take for the capacitor to charge to 63% of the battery voltage?

A) Initial current: 3A, Time to 63% charge: 0.3 ms
B) Initial current: 9A, Time to 63% charge: 0.3 ms
C) Initial current: 3A, Time to 63% charge: 0.3 s
D) Initial current: 9A, Time to 63% charge: 0.3 s

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: 
The total resistance in the circuit is 3 Ω (2 Ω from capacitor + 1 Ω from battery). The initial current can be calculated using Ohm's law: I = V/R = 9V / 3Ω = 3A.

The RC time constant is calculated as T = R * C = 3Ω * 100μF = 300μs = 0.3 ms. This is the time it takes for the capacitor to charge to 63% of the final voltage.

Option B is incorrect because it overestimates the initial current. Options C and D are incorrect because they state the time in seconds instead of milliseconds.

\#\#\# User: I've been using the Mac Mini with Dell U2711 monitor for couple days and only now I've realized what is wrong: The display isn't using its maximum resolution 2560x1440 but the 1080p which the OS reports as the max resolution. I then read from the Apple's site that for some reason 1080p is the maximum resolution when using the HDMI\-connector.

The Mac Mini contains only HDMI and Thunderbolt connectors, at least according to Apple's site. The Dell\-monitor doesn't have Thunderbolt but instead it has VGA, DVI, DisplayPort and HDMI. 

So my question is: Is it possible to get the maximum resolution out of my monitor?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Thunderbolt contains a DisplayPort channel. You can get a Thunderbolt/Mini DisplayPort to DisplayPort cable. I found a cheap one on [Monoprice](http://monoprice.com) a while back. [Here](http://www.monoprice.com/products/product.asp?c_id=102&cp_id=10246&cs_id=1024606&p_id=6007&seq=1&format=2) is a 6 footer.

20.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: A user has a Mac Mini connected to a Dell U2711 monitor via HDMI, but is unable to achieve the monitor's maximum resolution of 2560x1440. Which of the following solutions would allow the user to utilize the monitor's full resolution?

A) Purchase a VGA to HDMI adapter
B) Use a Thunderbolt to DisplayPort cable
C) Enable a hidden setting in macOS to unlock higher HDMI resolutions
D) Upgrade to a newer Mac Mini model with native 4K HDMI support

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The Mac Mini's HDMI port is limited to 1080p resolution, but its Thunderbolt port includes DisplayPort functionality. The Dell U2711 monitor has a DisplayPort input. By using a Thunderbolt to DisplayPort cable, the user can bypass the HDMI limitation and achieve the monitor's full 2560x1440 resolution. Option A won't work because VGA doesn't support such high resolutions. Option C is incorrect as there's no hidden setting to unlock higher HDMI resolutions on this Mac Mini model. Option D is unnecessary, as the current hardware can support the desired resolution with the correct cable.

\#\#\# User: [This question](https://softwareengineering.stackexchange.com/questions/62302/most-common-one-line-bugs-in-c#question) was migrated from SO to Programmers. It was marked community wiki on SO, but it looks like that's been cleared on Programmers. 

I can't quite tell if the last answer was made before or after the migration, but at 43 answers the question should've been wikified automatically if a mod didn't explicitly convert it.

Did CW status get cleared in migration? If so, should it be or is that a bug?

Edit: the mod actions pop\-up has the option to "Remove wiki" enabled and "Convert to wiki" is greyed out. This suggests to me that the post should still be CW, even though the question and answers don't say so.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Good idea. We should definitely add more friction here.

From this point on, **if there are more than (certain threshold \- see below) answers** ...

* [the answers' unupvoted comments will be collapsed](https://workplace.meta.stackexchange.com/q/2899)
* the post editor will be initially hidden
* there will be a button titled "Answer This Question"
* clicking it will produce this dialog:

> This question has more than {x} answers already.
> 
> 
> Did you read through all the existing answers first to make sure your answer will be contributing something new?
> 
> 
> Also, please note that you can click the edit link on any of these answers to improve them.

So, perhaps that will at least remind folks that once there are a lot of answers, they should really think twice about adding a new one to the pile \-\- and maybe click that "edit" button instead.

![this question has more than 30 answers already.](https://i.stack.imgur.com/Lknb7.png)

The thresholds may change, and are configurable per site, but currently they are:

* 30 on most sites
* [2 on The Workplace](https://workplace.meta.stackexchange.com/a/2931)
* [5 on Software Engineering](https://softwareengineering.meta.stackexchange.com/q/8685/173647)
* [10 on Interpersonal Skills](https://interpersonal.meta.stackexchange.com/q/2361/)
* [15 on Super User](https://meta.superuser.com/q/274)
* [100 on Ask Patents](https://chat.meta.stackexchange.com/transcript/message/6701143)
* [200 on Photography](https://chat.meta.stackexchange.com/transcript/message/6701143)
* [500 on Code Golf](https://codegolf.meta.stackexchange.com/posts/comments/2859)

Back when we automatically converted certain questions to community wiki, these were the thresholds used for one of the automatic conversion criteria. We no longer do such conversions, but still set the old thresholds for this feature, so this is why collapsing comments and showing this message are currently tied to the same threshold.

Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: On Stack Exchange sites, what happens when a question reaches a certain threshold of answers?

A) The question is automatically deleted
B) All new answers are automatically converted to comments
C) New answers require moderator approval before posting
D) Additional friction is added for posting new answers

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: According to the documentation, when a question reaches a certain threshold of answers (which varies by site), several measures are implemented to add friction to posting new answers:

1. Unupvoted comments on answers are collapsed
2. The post editor is initially hidden
3. A button titled "Answer This Question" appears
4. Clicking this button shows a dialog reminding users to check existing answers and consider editing instead of adding a new answer

These measures are designed to encourage users to thoroughly review existing answers and potentially improve them rather than adding redundant information. The specific threshold varies by site, ranging from as low as 2 on The Workplace to as high as 500 on Code Golf.

The other options are incorrect:
A) Questions are not automatically deleted based on answer count.
B) New answers are not converted to comments.
C) There is no mention of requiring moderator approval for new answers.

\#\#\# User: I own a condo, built in 1961\. I've started remodeling and in tearing out my kitchen I discovered the wall between me and my neighbors is only that: a wall. No fire protection just drywall, regular (old) insulation and drywall. Any simple suggestions besides tearing down all the drywall?

I'll be installing Roxul Safe'n'Sound™ in the interior walls. 

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Type X drywall, which is typically 5/8" thick (as opposed to 1/2") and contains fiberglass within the gypsum is typically used for fire protection. I believe it increases the burn through time to around 1 hour, and it increases the impact resistance (there's often falling debris in a fire). For further protection, every electrical junction box should be enclosed around the back, top, and bottom with 2x4's and plywood to prevent fires from burning through the box, or a fire that starts in the box from spreading quickly to the other side. Additionally, every penetration in the wall should be sealed with fire rated caulking (it's typically orange in color, and they also have a similar expanding foam of the same color, so it's easy for the building inspector to verify you used the correct product).

The safe and sound insulation is a great addition. The only other thing you could do is to add a 1" air gap and a second wall on your side, which would help with both the spread of fire and sound, but the downside is that you'd lose almost 6" of space in your kitchen.

Realize that no structure will be fire proof, the goal is to slow the spread until the fire department can get there. And the last small fire I saw in a townhouse resulted in half a dozen engines, ladder trucks, etc, because they take the risk of a spreading fire very seriously.

23.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: A homeowner is renovating their 1961 condo and discovers that the wall shared with their neighbor lacks proper fire protection. Which combination of measures would provide the most comprehensive fire protection without significantly reducing living space?

A) Install Type X drywall, seal electrical junction boxes with 2x4s and plywood, use fire-rated caulking for wall penetrations
B) Add a 1" air gap and a second wall, install Roxul Safe'n'Sound™ insulation, use regular drywall
C) Use regular drywall, install Roxul Safe'n'Sound™ insulation, seal electrical junction boxes with fire-rated foam
D) Install Type X drywall, use regular insulation, add a 1" air gap and a second wall

Correct Answer: A

Explanation: Option A provides the most comprehensive fire protection without significantly reducing living space. Type X drywall offers enhanced fire resistance and impact protection. Sealing electrical junction boxes with 2x4s and plywood prevents fire spread through these vulnerable points. Using fire-rated caulking for wall penetrations further enhances fire containment. This combination addresses multiple aspects of fire protection without requiring the addition of a second wall, which would reduce living space.

Option B includes adding a second wall, which would significantly reduce living space. While it includes Safe'n'Sound insulation, it lacks the fire-resistant properties of Type X drywall and doesn't address junction boxes or penetrations.

Option C uses regular drywall, which lacks the fire-resistant properties of Type X drywall. While it includes Safe'n'Sound insulation, the use of fire-rated foam for junction boxes is not as comprehensive as the plywood and 2x4 method.

Option D combines Type X drywall with a second wall, which would provide good fire protection but at the cost of significant living space reduction. It also uses regular insulation instead of the fire-resistant Safe'n'Sound, and doesn't address junction boxes or penetrations.

\#\#\# User: Our university has an Honors section of our "liberal arts mathematics" course. Typically 10\-20 students enroll each Fall, with most of them extremely bright, but lacking the interest and/or mathematics background of many of the students we usually see in calculus.

I've taught this section twice already: once using the really good book on voting and apportionment methods by Jonathan Hodge and Richard Klima, and another topology course centered around Jeff Weeks' *The Shape of Space*. 

Next Fall, however, I'd like to run more of a reading seminar course, in which students read and discuss several shorter books and papers aimed at a general audience. I'm having trouble however coming up with a good list of titles. So far I'm thinking of *Flatland* and *Innumeracy*. Not bad choices, but I was hoping for some more "mathematical" readings. 

Any suggestions of books and/or papers? Maybe some specific expository articles in the MAA's Monthly?

Thanks.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: Rather than suggest specific topics, which must be your personal choice, let me recommend three
collections as possible sources:

(1\) Brian Hayes' collection, *[Group Theory in the Bedroom and Other Mathematical Diversions](http://grouptheoryinthebedroom.com/)*. Every chapter is quite good,
and the title chapter is a gem. 

(2\) *[The Best Writing on Mathematics 2010](http://press.princeton.edu/titles/9526.html)* and *2011*. The Forwards (by William Thurston
and Freeman Dyson respectively) are already worth the price of admission. Thurston:
"I have decided that daydreaming is not a bug but a feature." :\-)

(3\) The AMS series, *[What's Happening in the Mathematical Sciences](http://www.ams.org/bookstore/happeningseries)*, with many articles by Barry Cipra and Dana Mackenzie (some reprinted in *The Best Writing*).

24.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Based on the recommendations provided, which of the following would be the LEAST suitable source for selecting readings for an Honors liberal arts mathematics course aimed at bright students lacking advanced math background?

A) "Group Theory in the Bedroom and Other Mathematical Diversions" by Brian Hayes
B) "The Best Writing on Mathematics" annual collections
C) "What's Happening in the Mathematical Sciences" series by AMS
D) A graduate-level textbook on abstract algebra

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: Options A, B, and C are all recommended in the answer as good sources for accessible mathematical reading material suitable for bright students without advanced math backgrounds. These collections contain expository articles and essays aimed at a general audience, which aligns with the course goals described.

Option D, a graduate-level textbook on abstract algebra, would be far too advanced and specialized for the target audience described in the question. It would not fit the desire for "more of a reading seminar course" with materials "aimed at a general audience." This makes it the least suitable option for this particular course.

\#\#\# User: Inspired by the author's motivation for asking [Is there a BNF grammar of tex language](https://tex.stackexchange.com/questions/4201/is-there-a-bnf-grammar-of-tex-language).

Are there any well done libraries that can parse some subset of TeX mathematics independently of the TeX engine? Important points to consider in answers:

* How large of a subset of TeX mathematical notation is supported?
* Is the parser portable? Does it have any dependencies?
* Is the parser closely tied to a particular backend or could it easily be used to support multiple output formats. In other words, how easily could it be integrated into a new system that had to support output to PDF, HTML, PNG, etc.

For example, I know of the following parsers but not much about their applicability outside the use cases for which they were designed (Matplotlib graphics and math rendering in web browsers):

* The [mathematical expression](http://matplotlib.sourceforge.net/users/mathtext.html#mathtext-tutorial) handler in Python's Matplotlib.
* The [MathJax](http://www.mathjax.org) rendering library for JavaScript.

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: I've been looking into this too, so I'll share some observations that fall rather short of a proper answer, which would really involve looking at a whole lot of source code and asking the right questions about it.

**Parsers generating HTML\+Math ML**

1. Nick Drakos \& Ross Moore's [Latex2html](http://www.tug.org/mailman/listinfo/latex2html) converter, written in Perl, which I think was the first converter to map equations to Math ML. In 1998, Ross Moore outlined [his goals for Latex2html](http://www.geom.uiuc.edu/~ross/webtex/webtex/), tied to the now defunct, closed\-source WebEq mathematics rendering software, and Webtex, which was an alternative syntax for mathematics designed for use in web pages. From [the WebEq documentation](http://www.sungchichu.com:8080/WebEQ.3.7/docs/reference/WebTeX/wtxsec1.html): *WebTeX always translates unambiguously into MathML, while LaTeX does not*.
2. [itex2mml](http://golem.ph.utexas.edu/~distler/blog/itex2MML.html), in C by Paul Gartside \& others, also based on Webtex, but with support for some Latex not supported in Webtex.
3. [tex4ht](http://www.tug.org/tex4ht/), written in C by Eitan Gurari and other eminent figures. It avoids having to parse Latex source by running `latex` with modified macros that insert specials into the DVI output, and parses the DVI output instead.
4. John McFarlan's [Pandoc](http://johnmacfarlane.net/pandoc/), as mentioned by Aditya, written in Haskell. Note that Pandoc supports generation of HTML, both with and without Math ML.
5. MathJax allows generation of Math ML besides the usual boxes plus image fonts output. It has [an impressive degree of support for Latex](http://www.mathjax.org/resources/docs/?tex.html#supported-latex-commands), including limited support for user macros.

**Parsers generating XML**

Jason Blevins has a list of tools that convert Latex documents to XML\-based formats, and that handle equations reasonably. Romeo Anghelache's [Hermes](http://hermes.roua.org/), which is part of a full Latex parser that generates XML with semantic markup, is worth singling out: like tex4ht, it works by running the Tex engine with macros to put specials in the DVI output, which it then parses; it supports a wider set of semantic markup. 

**Fragments of Latex or DVI**

With the exception of the systems referencing Webtex, there doesn't seem to be much interest in clearly codifying subsets of Latex to be parsed, I guess because these are regarded as moving targets. Instead, lists of commands supported, like that I mentioned for Mathjax, seems to be the way things are done.

With DVI\-based converters, the issue of parsing Latex goes away, replaced by the relatively trivial issue of parsing marked\-up DVI and the trickier issue of identifying the semantically significant macros and constructing markup\-issuing replacements that do not improperly interfere. I haven't looked at how this is done for equational layout. It would be a useful exercise to see how a converter from Tex formulae to those of It's worth noting that the representation of expressions is essentially a superset of that used by Heckmann \& Wilhelm (1997\) would work.

**Syntax highlighting**

A completely different kind of parsing is involved in syntax highlighting, where the idea is to help the author see the significance of the parts of the formulae. I don't know of any syntax highlighters that do an interesting job here: Auctex only raisers/lowers super\&subscripts, but i haven't really looked.

**Reference**

Heckmann \& Wilhelm, 1997, [A Functional Description of TeX's Formula Layout](http://rw4.cs.uni-sb.de/~heckmann/abstracts/neuform.html).

25.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the given documentation:

Question: Which of the following statements about TeX mathematics parsers is most accurate?

A) MathJax is primarily designed for parsing TeX and generating PDF output.

B) Latex2html was one of the earliest converters to map equations to MathML, and it's written in C.

C) tex4ht parses LaTeX source directly to generate HTML and MathML output.

D) Pandoc, written in Haskell, supports generation of HTML both with and without MathML for mathematical expressions.

Correct Answer: D

Explanation: 
A is incorrect because MathJax is primarily a rendering library for JavaScript, not for generating PDF output.

B is partially correct about Latex2html being an early converter to MathML, but it's written in Perl, not C.

C is incorrect because tex4ht doesn't parse LaTeX source directly. Instead, it runs latex with modified macros to insert specials into the DVI output, which it then parses.

D is correct. The documentation mentions that John McFarlan's Pandoc is written in Haskell and supports generation of HTML, both with and without MathML for mathematical expressions.

\#\#\# User: I just upgraded to iOS 10, and I see that there's a Reminders widget on my lock screen. I added a couple of test reminders to the Reminders app, but they don't appear on my lock screen. If I touch the Reminders widget on the lock screen, I'm taken to the Reminders app (after logging in), and there my reminders are visible. What do I have to do to get my reminders to show up on my lock screen?

 \-

\#\#\# Top Answer: The Reminders widget only shows upcoming reminders. That is, those with a date/time set for them, and that date/time is still in the future. If you set reminders without a date/time, they will not show in the widget.

26.answer:
Here's a multi-form question based on the provided documentation:

Question: Sarah recently upgraded her iPhone to iOS 10 and noticed a new Reminders widget on her lock screen. She created several reminders in the Reminders app, but they don't appear on the lock screen widget. Which of the following actions would most likely cause Sarah's reminders to show up on the lock screen?

A) Restarting the iPhone
B) Setting a date and time for each reminder
C) Increasing the font size of the reminders
D) Enabling notifications for the Reminders app

Correct Answer: B

Explanation: The Reminders widget on the iOS 10 lock screen only displays upcoming reminders that have a specific date and time set for them. Reminders without a date/time will not appear in the widget. Therefore, setting a date and time for each reminder is the most likely action to make them visible on the lock screen.

Option A is incorrect because restarting the iPhone wouldn't affect how reminders are displayed on the lock screen.

Option C is incorrect because font size doesn't determine whether reminders appear on the lock screen widget.

Option D is incorrect because while enabling notifications might affect how reminders alert the user, it doesn't directly influence their appearance on the lock screen widget.
